moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6: the phillidor defence. in my opinion it is a forgotten opening that should be stay that way.
moves.3. h3: why h3? what is wrong with good old Bc4 or d4?
moves.3... a6: what is black afraid of? why not Nf6?
moves.4. d4 exd4 5. Nxd4 h6: ?? a wait of time. Nf6 is needed with Be7 and 0-0 following.
moves.6. Nc3 Nf6 7. Bd3: maybe c4 is a better spot for that bishop.
moves.7... Be7 8. Nf5: I prefer 0-0 with f4, Qe2 and e5.
moves.8... Bxf5 9. exf5 d5: I think that 0-0 with Nd7-Ne5 is better than d5.
moves.10. O-O b5 11. a3 c5: gets lots of space to play in the queen side but black did not castle yet and has got two pieces in the queen side that are not in the game yet...
moves.12. Re1 c4 13. Be2: the Bishop will stand proudly on f3 and will press hard on d5...
moves.14... Ra7 15. Nxd5 Nxd5 16. Qxd5 Qxd5 17: with a pawn up, white's life should be easier.
moves.18... Bf6 19. c3: "locks" the queen side and prepering to move with the c1 bishop an the a1 rook.
moves.19... Re7 20. Bf4 Nd7 21. Bd6: ! forces black to exchange rooks. white should notice that the pawn chain that black has in the queen side is in the color of his bishop and the bishop that black has is in the opposite color so he cannot defend them.
moves.21... Rxe1+ 22. Rxe1 Rd8 23. Be7 Bxe7 24:
? giving black the chance for a draw:
26... Rd1  27. Re1 Rd2 28. Re2 Rd1  and so on...
moves.28... a5 29. Bc6 b4 30. axb4 axb4 31. cx: with that great advantage black should resign...
